text.p: WorldCom Inc said on Tuesday that the two companies have completed their $12.6 billion stock swap merger.
Each share of MFS will be converted into the right to receive 2.1 shares of WorldCom common stock, WorldCom said.
Preferred shares of MFS will be converted into preferred shares of WorldCom, the company said.
The combined companies will do business under the name WorldCom and will offer a broad range of local, long distance, international, and Internet services, WorldCom said.

Prior to the merger, MFS provided local calling service to businesses, while WorldCom is a long distance and international carrier. MFS had acquired UUNET, a provider of Internet services, in August 1996 for $2 billion.
Cost savings between the two companies will be achieved from reduced line and access costs and the elimination of duplicate capital spending, WorldCom said.
The deal, however, is expected to be dilutive to the combined companies' earnings for three years, WorldCom said.
